Yes, long-ball tactics are also commonly used in football tournaments, especially when a team has a striker who is strong, fast, and good at holding up the ball. In this style of play, the team plays long balls up the field from their own half to the opponent's half, hoping for their striker to win the ball or flick it on to a teammate. This strategy is useful when the team is under pressure or wants to bypass the midfield and quickly move the ball up the field.

However, long-ball tactics can be risky, as the team can lose possession of the ball quickly if the striker fails to keep the ball or if the opposition's defenders intercept the ball. As such, it is important for teams that use this tactic to have a strong defense to handle counter-attacks from the opposition.
